pros: Academic Programs: DePaul offers a wide range of academic programs across various disciplines. It is particularly well-known for its business, law, computer science, and performing arts programs. Urban Campus: The university's urban campus provides a unique learning environment. Students can easily explore the city, intern at local businesses, and engage with the community. Location: DePaul University is located in Chicago, one of the most vibrant and culturally diverse cities in the United States. Students have access to numerous cultural institutions, job opportunities, and networking events.
cons: Commuter Campus: Due to its urban setting, DePaul has a significant number of commuter students who live off-campus. While this can provide flexibility, it may affect the sense of community and campus engagement for some students. Weather: Chicago experiences harsh winters, and the weather can be a challenge for those who are not accustomed to cold temperatures and snow. This may impact outdoor activities and travel during certain times of the year.

cons: Company doesn't care about professional development of employees if there is a cost outside of what is offered as a standard class. No room for advancement if you don't "appeal" to the right people. Promotions are not merit based, they are based on favoritism regardless of capability. Poor salary. Bonuses only if you have a manager who advocates for you and values you regardless of merit. As an employee, I faced racism/sexism/ageism from other staff and as a student from professors. I reported it the first few times and nothing happened so I stopped (which is typical of a university culture).

job_title: Senior Business Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Benefits were great (PTO, health care, etc.) and competitive.

The commute was easy thanks to the CTA.

I had two (faculty) bosses over 3.5 years: one was alright and the other was outstanding.
cons:
Department staff were overworked with no relief in sight. Budgets kept shrinking and layoffs were wide-spread. Compensation didn't reflect the amount of work everyone was doing. Morale was incredibly low when I left.

Working as a staff person with faculty bosses was tough. Tenured faculty operate differently and can have difficulty advocating for staff who report to them.

For years, I experienced harassment by a tenured/well-connected professor -- little changed even after an investigation established a strong pattern of sexist behavior. This was a major disappointment and contributed to my departure.

review_title: Make a difference while maintaining balance
pros: Work/life balance. You won't make as much as your average corporate job, but you get a 35-40 hour week leaving time for your other interests, loved ones or volunteer activities. 100k+ a year will never buy back time working on your personal projects or personal relationships. Workload is reasonable, fairly relaxed work environment despite odd dress codes in some places, people are professional, facilities are up to date and the U is growing. Lots of material benefits in the form of 'demon discounts'. If you can find a position you enjoy and can make it work, there's a fair chance it's yours for the rest of your career.
cons: Because of the lower salary grading the U has trouble attracting talent which leads to some positions being less than useful due to who has been hired. Further, you may find that folks with "low" grades are particularly fresh and experienced and will struggle to find purpose within the organization and will eventually leave as a result of not being empowered or recognized. Unless you're in an office that's growing there's little room for advancement and good positions tend to be occupied for many years if not decades. As with most locations in higher ed, there is bureaucracy but DePaul moves more quickly than others. Despite this, change may happen too slow for those outside higher ed and the pace can be excruciating to those from fast-paced work environments.

pros:
Great colleagues, innovative programs, frontline camaraderie.

Chairing my department has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my life.  I really can't say enough about the intellectual engagement of my colleagues, their willingness to think across disciplinary boundaries, or their commitment to students.
cons:
Leadership disaster.

DePaul became one of the largest private universities in the country during the 1990s.  That growth was absolutely key to its fiscal model, since tuition contributes virtually all of its revenue and its small endowment is used to leverage debt.  Unfortunately, the university is no longer growing and the leadership is floundering.  The president is off on sabbatical at Harvard this term, while the provost's office is a revolving door (three short-term incumbents in the past three years, one of them serving twice), and three deans have retired or left in the past year.  The Board of Trustees has decided to impose a hiring freeze in all but name, freeze salaries, and ratchet up the use of non-tenure-track faculty.  Millions of dollars are squandered on a losing men's basketball team and vanity projects.  In order to prop up enrollments in the short term, career preparation is now emphasized at the expense of core academic programs.  With a tuition sticker price of over $30K and inadequate financial aid that makes the real cost of DePaul higher than that of Northwestern or the University of Chicago for many students, DePaul now finds itself as the Sears of higher education: a Target-quality product at Nieman Marcus prices.

review_title: Major flaws, but still a good place to work
pros: I'm a product of DePaul. I started working for DePaul as a receptionist after getting my graduate degree here, which I got specifically to work in the higher ed industry. You can't beat the benefits package at DePaul, especially tuition reimbursement. I was able to get a second graduate degree (in education) thanks to this benefit. I've been in several departments and the work culture varies, but typically, DePaul is more laid-back than other Chicago universities. The Loop is a bit more formal than LPC. Either way, DePaul strives for work-life balance and tries to put people first.
cons: My job description is that of a receptionist. I'm the lowest pay grade (under <$30K). But the work I am doing far exceeds a receptionist's (think budget management, advising, office management, etc.).  Looking at other descriptions, I should be in the third bracket if not higher, but in the budget crisis, it looks like there's no room for growth and it's more cost effective to tack on duties after-the-fact. For a young person trained and educated here, looking to grow, it's disheartening.

pros: DePaul is located in a great urban environment, which makes it a great place to do research in diverse settings.
cons: I was there for five years as a doctoral student and taught undergraduate psych courses during my final three years there.  As a student, stipends are not nearly enough to live on (less than 16k per year in 2012), resources to complete work (computers, printers, software, a desk, etc.) were scarce, and most faculty have little concern for students' progressive success.  Unless you're doing their work for them, little support is offered.  As an instructor, the undergraduate students appear to be running the show and diluting the quality of learning by constantly demanding 'what's going to be on the test', and very often not taking responsibility for their own learning.  As a male instructor in a female-dominated field and psych department, I received little support when holding students accountable for assignments and learning.  Disagreements with the lead faculty, including the Chair and Program Directors, are often met with unnecessary resistance which impede the career progress of their own graduate students.  (Not only would I not recommend working there, I would not want my children to go to school there).

review_title: Toxic, soul-sucking, miserable place to work!
pros: The mission of DePaul is worthy and noble: to be part of positive change in the world and to help those on the margins. It's a wonderful mission and the faculty and students are doing amazing things. Unfortunately, this doesn't extend to the atmosphere for staff.
cons:
Where to begin? First, they pay well below any kind of competitive rate except for the fundraisers who are valued above all else. The rest of the staff are paid terribly and there are no raises or a chance for a promotion...EVER! They do give cost of living increases but these are piddly and even these are sometimes withheld.

Then there is the environment, which is rigid and controlling and toxic with bullying bosses, no accountability and a culture of fear. Managers also do not ever give positive feedback.

There is a huge disconnect between the mission of the university and how staff are treated and compensated. If you read the website, it's full of lies about how they value their staff and pay them competitive wages, etc. 

There is a huge turnover rate and it's not random. It's because of the culture and the way staff are treated. They don't care. People are disposable and dispensible to them.  They would rather just hire someone else at very little money than bother to nurture and treat their current employees the way they deserve to be treated.

review_title: It all depends on your department and the leadership (or lack thereof) in the department.
pros: The benefits are great and in general other staff members are friendly and easy to work with. Also, most staff members try hard to support students and help students develop and grow during their time at DePaul.
cons: It can be very difficult to advance to a new position at the University. The HR Department is not very responsive if you are trying to switch to a new position. Some departments are very well managed and in some departments no one even knows who the manager is because that person is never at work.

review_title: Great, mission-driven company with great benefits
pros: DePaul is a great place to work for many reasons. It is a mission-driven institution that embodies and fulfills the mission of St. Vincent DePaul. Work life balance is important and they support life-long learning. Benefits are great. 3 weeks vacation to begin, 403B plan and they match up to 8.5%, 1.5 weeks of vacation when the university closes for the holidays, tuition benefit for you, your spouse and your children, and the list goes on. Great people work here and the students are great as well.
cons: Opportunity for growth can be limited in management positions. Many high level managers stay at DePaul for 20+ years which doesn't open up opportunities for people to move up. In addition, the internal hiring process is extremely disorganized. A current employee can apply for a position and never hear back or when they do hear back, it's months after the position has been filled. That's not a good way to treat current employees.

review_title: My experience as a part-time, non-tenure track instructor
pros: DePaul is not immune to the general deterioration of academic departments across the country, but compared to most, it's an institution that values individual instruction and fosters a sense of community involvement and passion for social justice amongst its students. It is a joy to teach students who are both prepared to succeed and/or passionate about the field they want to go into. And, for what it's worth, I've had plenty of opportunities to interact with the administration as well as the tenured and tenure-track professors in my department, in spite of my part-time position.
cons: Commuting can be difficult to both the Loop and Lincoln park campuses, be prepared to pay for parking on your own dime. If you're commuting from Greater Chicagoland, consider Metra or CTA park-and-ride from Midway, Harlem, or Howard depending on which direction you're coming from.

review_title: Stay away from JTR Library Jobs
pros: I can't think of a single one.
cons: I worked as a circulation assistant at the Richardson Library for one year as a student worker. To say that library staff/admin treats student workers terribly is an understatement. Hours are extremely inflexible -- I dropped two classes as a  because I could not get out of my shift 5 minutes early to make it to class across the street. Training was also inadequate and supervisors would throw a binder at me and instruct me to "read the book" if I had a question or threaten to terminate my employment via email, rather than just explaining or showing me how to do something in the database.   I was verbally abused and harassed by a supervisor (not my direct report), had my internet search history combed through when I briefly walked away from my desk, and she referred to me as "dumber than a bag of bricks." I promptly left my position and did not give 2 weeks notice, I could not take the fear of going into work every morning for a minimum wage, part- time student position, all the while being treated with zero respect or dignity as a full-time student trying to pay my way through school.

review_title: Great School with an Amazing foundation....Leadership Development Needed
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: DePaul has an amazing foundation with great intention. The mission state is inspiring typically well represented. The ministry is always trying to support all different backgrounds. They also have AMAZING benefits. Even if you get short changed on salary, benefits will make up for those shortcomings.
cons: However, the leadership is mostly not great around the board. There isn't much transparency. I gave this place a three star because core is great and once some leadership finally leave, hopefully it will be replaced with individuals with interpersonal skills and the ability to motivate staff, instead of being scared to even talk to staff.

review_title: Nepotism taints and covers up management errors, bullying and harassment
pros: Tuition reimbursement.  Academic side of the University is wonderful and want to help students.   caring staff and professors enjoy what they do and the staff helps to make sure students are made the priority.
cons: My manager and coworker who my manager hired bullied and harassed me.  I made several written complaints to HR and the ombudsman as "policy" advises, however, policy was overlooked and they weren't disciplined.  How can bullying be allowed when their is an anti bullying policy?  Well it happened to me!  I was more qualified for the managers role but she was placed in that role because of nepotism.  I applied for jobs throughout the university and my manager made sure to  sabotage those efforts.  So much for adherence to policy and procedures and living the Vincentian way!  Turnover at the university is overwhelming because issues get brushed under the rug and victims quit and my manger gets unwarranted bonuses!  This place needs to be audited for misuse of funds!

pros:
-Many people at DePaul recognize and value the humanistic mission of St. Vincent DePaul. 
-Full time is 35 hrs/week
-Good retirement matching
-Good amount of PTO, including summer hours and a week off between Christmas and New Years that doesn't detract from vacation days
-Tuition benefit for you, your spouse/partner, children
cons:
-Low enrollment is causing financial troubles
-There have been huge gaps in leadership lately - No provost in the last three years, senior people are often leaving to go on sabbatical elsewhere even though the university needs support
-Somewhat shady admission processes that are rumored to benefit students who attended high school in higher income zip codes, which seems completely screwed up and counter to their mission. 
-Not a lot of room for individual advancement once you are hired into a position. 
-While benefits are good, professional staff salaries are often lower than market rates for comparable positions (this is not uncommon in higher ed)

pros: Depends on which office you work in and who your supervisor is -- some supervisors can't help but micromanage to the point of trying to control what you use your vacation time for!  Others are very relaxed. Lincoln Park has plenty to do during your lunch break and the Ray Meyer fitness center has good classes and nice facilities.
cons: Eliminates positions and puts the responsibility on remaining staff without an increase in compensation or other benefits.  Pay is mediocre, and don't expect much of a raise even if you have worked really hard.  Performance Appraisals are rarely accurate -- even if you have "Exceeded Expectations" in all or most areas, your supervisor probably won't mark that on the actual form because then they'll actually have to give you a raise or some kind of promotion.

pros: The benefits are great, 401k, vacations, work and life balance. Not a very stressful environment. Lot's of free time to do a degree with tuition reimbursement.
cons: Advancement is very hard to go by, a lot of senior people who have been there for a long time will get the nice projects and be always busy. Associate level and younger people don't see a lot of action. Trusts takes a long time to be established. Lot's of micro management, managers will only give small task that can be executed quickly.They call them projects but these tasks are definitely not important enough to be called projects.

review_title: Great place to work full-time. But full-time work is hard to get.
job_title: Prefer Not to Answer. We Are A Small Staff. in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros:
Great reputation. A good atmosphere and nice people. If you are not part-time, there are a lot more reasons to work there. 
As a part-time job, it's a good environment and a respectful environment. Could be more challenging. The hourly wage is better than most comparable jobs. No complaints there. However, limited available hours and no benefits makes it a difficult place to stay if you need to make a living.
cons: If you are full-time, it's a wonderful place. If you are part-time, it's very difficult to move up with the University to a full-time position. So...no benefits, paid vacation, or tuition breaks.

review_title: Student Worker Position in Academic Department
pros: Flexible schedule; friendly co-workers; pay raises for good work; great networking; ability to work on homework during downtime; encouragement to pursue internships and other academic pursuits (even if it means leaving position); wide range of responsibilities
cons: Not much opportunity for advancement; minimum wage for new employees; you are the "bottom of the food chain" and are sometimes treated as such (blamed for circumstances outside of your control, you'll have to do the grunt work that no one else wants to do); office politics tend to be magnified with professors

pros: The emphasis on good teaching is for real at DePaul, not just a catchphrase.    Although there are always exceptions, the general profile of a DePaul professor is a person to whom high standards for teaching are important.
cons: Benefits for part-time and adjunct faculty are not very generous.   although the pay scale for an adjunct faculty at DePaul are towards the higher end of Chicago universities, it's like being at the top of a really low barrel.

review_title: It all depends on the enviorment that you are given in the beginning of the year
pros:
The benefits of working at DePaul as a Resident Advisor go as followed:

- Free Housing
- Small stipend (about $600-700 per quarter)
- Being able to live on campus.
cons: The work enviorment can get hectic beecause you are trying to balance school and work. When it isn't finals or midterms it is usually pretty easy going however that all depends on your boss. If you have a terrible supervisor be ready to put in more work than you want to.

pros: There are some really smart and nice people that work there. Great campus, get to work in the city. Great access to the best of Chicago. Employees get free education. The benefits are nice. People are generally super nice.
cons: It's hard to give a review because it totally depends on what department you work in. Like many universities, the staff in one department can be totally from another department. The higher ed industry is also a challenging place to be in right now, since the education model in the US is being turned upside down, with 4 year institutions dwindling in value. This means limited opportunities to grow.

review_title: RInn Law Library is staffed by lazy, ignorant people
pros: Vacation over the Christmas break.
cons: Lazy and mean management, terrible salary, student workers are lazy and hide from work. They are meant to be helping law students, but the management is not interested in that. They get angry if you call them to come out of their offices to answer questions for students. They do not know basic law terms. Astonishing! Horrible treatment of staff. Turnover was constant for the job I had. Everyone else was a lifer. There was a robbery of a purse and a laptop while I worked there because no one kept out the bums. Just horrible in every way.

review_title: Not a bad place to work, but the salaries could be better.
pros: DePaul gives its employees free tuition not only for staff members, but for spouses and children too.  The health benefits cannot be matched and they give us a week and a half off paid during the holidays.  The work is not difficult, but some people stay here for 20, 30 or more years and they can be set in their ways and difficult to work with.  Overall, it is not a bad place to work.
cons: You'll never get rich here.  The salaries are a bit low, even if you have a Master's degree.  It's hard to advance and sometimes there's  a lot of office politics.

review_title: A great place to work but...
pros: Great work - life balance.  Very caring and supportive environment.  Not corporate at all.  Great vacation benefits - and great only working a 35 hour work week.
cons: Full of the red tape and politics that goes along with higher education.  Too many people who are promoted because they have just been there - people get comfortable doing very little and that becomes the status quo.

pros:
* Flexible hours
* Only assigned to courses you've taken/got a good grade in
* A good refresher of the material
* Relatively great pay
cons:
* Grading style has to constantly change based on the professor you're grading for
* Very mundane at times, and yet you have to keep on your highest alert, as otherwise you'll potentially give someone a grade lower than they deserve
* Different professors expect different things (e.g. varying level of comments, overall reviews, charts and tracking of grades)

pros: DePaul seems to care about their employees. In less than one year, I've had more opportunities for development and personal growth than 12 years at my last job. From benefits, to listening to employee feedback, I get a sense that my input is both valued and respected. Even in such a large university I see that my individual work is important and valuable. My manager's style is open and hands off leaving me to complete my work in my own way while still supporting me when I reach out for advice.
cons: Faculty are treated much better than staff, but I believe this is true just about everywhere.

review_title: Good support for adjunct faculty (compared to other schools).
pros: Students are generally very bright and motivated. The University has solid administration and helpful benefits for faculty. Full-time faculty in many of the departments are supportive and engaging. The social justice mission is emphasized throughout.
cons: Adjunct pay is not great--although DePaul is better than some schools in this respect, it is still very low. Although the Dean and Department Chairs look out for their faculty, without a contract, courses can be cancelled one week into the start if enrollment is too low. The office space for adjuncts is shared and small.

job_title: Student Program Assistant in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Working with and for faculty is always a joy. They are generally much more laid back than administrative staff. Most student workers have pretty flexible working hours which are often built around class schedules. This is really helpful convenient.
cons: Pay for student workers is generally minimum wage with only a few opportunities for raises. Administrative staff, in my experience, can be dismissive of work completed by student workers or their professional requests. This obviously varies across the colleges and departments within the University however.

pros: Being a student worker is mostly an easy job.  For the most part, responsibilities include answering phone calls and tending to walk-ins.  Extremely flexible hours that work with your schedule.
cons: There is little to no respect given to student workers and you are treated like a child.  The management is filled with office politics and the pay is pretty low.  Most of the people above you are on power trips and will go to great lengths to show they have the power to make you miserable.  I understand student workers are lowest on the totem pole but they should still be treated like a contributing part of the office.

review_title: DePaul is an amazing and creative place to work.
job_title: Training and Development Associate in Chicago, IL
pros:
Flexible work hours
Great Benefits
Mission Driven Workplace
Wonderful People
There are innovative and exciting projects to work on
Ample support from colleagues and management
Aware of and provide for a work-life balance.
cons:
Departmental Politics
Information Hoarding within some divisions
Difficult to find career paths.

review_title: Good room for growth and opportunities if you put in the time, but a sense of work community is lacking.
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Chicago, IL
pros: Institution is very laid back and supports a healthy work/life balance. If you’re willing to put in the time, there are opportunities to be had.
cons: Salary is lower than in industry, the university is currently contracting which comes along with the requisite layoffs and restrictions on spending, very little professional community within the institution.

review_title: Great Place to work, Excellent Benefits, Good Location with Low Pay, No chance for upward mobility
pros: Higher Education and Health care appear to be secure jobs. The benefits at DePaul are outstanding: free tuition, good medical/dental options, secure job, great location (although travel from outside the City can start to wear on you).
cons: Low pay, lack of career path

review_title: Decent benefits, poor compensation, and going downhill.
job_title: Information Services Employee in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
- Amazing benefits.  Three weeks off + two extra days + a free week off every December.  Good health insurance. 403(b) match is DePaul's 8% when you contribute 5%+.

- Short work days, most (full time) positions are only 35 hours a week.

- DePaul generally does seem to actually care about its mission of helping students and educating them.

- Good community, generally helpful employees in every department I've interacted with.

- Full tuition reimbursement for you, your spouse, and your children. Great place to be if you want to finish your masters or get multiple degrees.
cons:
- Pay is significantly under market, as in 20% to 30% lower than a compressible position at another company.

- Significant cutbacks have come to the budget as of the 2012-2013 year, and are continuing into the 2013-2014 year.  This has taken a toll on things like continuing education and resources available for employees.

- Perhaps normal for a large company, but relations between some departments can be EXTREMELY poor, which can make getting anything done outside of your own department or division very difficult and time consuming.

- Little or no communication from upper management about huge, university-wide decisions (The recent stadium debacle comes to mind - no one explained that to any of us. What am I supposed to say when people ask me about it?)

- Budget cutbacks led to some reduction in benefits, though they are admittedly still better than anywhere else around.

review_title: Many inspiring students, hit-or-miss faculty, and large, isolated administration
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros:
One of the best parts about working full-time at DePaul is the fringe benefits: 401k match up to 8%, fully vested; BCBS PPO health insurance option that includes Northwestern University Hospital system; 3 weeks vacation plus 1 week during the end-of-year holidays (for staff). Unlimited sick time, but you have to enroll in short-term disability if you exceed five consecutive days.

Another pro is the students. Many come from challenging environments and are determined to succeed in school. Most genuinely seem supportive of one another--I've seen a lot of kindness displayed in the classrooms and halls of DePaul. 

There are some faculty all-stars here, both in terms of publishing and in teaching, but many have, after achieving tenure, withdraw from an active scholarly life and are perfectly happy maintaining the status quo (though this is not uncommon in academia). 

On the staff side, I've met a number of extremely talented individuals as well as a handful of clueless types. Some positions are overworked and under-managed, others remain under-utilized and redundant. This seems to be more of a symptom of poor management than anything else.
cons: Low salaries compared to other similar institutions, both for staff and faculty; however, university administrators are paid more on average. Declines in enrollment, especially in graduate degree programs such as law and adult education (SNL), have resulted in both salary and hiring freezes. While health insurance premiums have remained stable in the past couple years, deductibles, out-of-pocket maximums, and co-pays are increasing in the next year (at least for the more expensive PPO plan). Little room for advancement unless you hold a terminal degree.

pros: Working with/for professors can lead to invaluable mentorship, in depth academic enrichment at phD level, even networking opportunities and employment.
cons: Rewarding nature of the position comes down entirely to which professor or professors you are assigned to. Many professors choose to abuse the free labor, overworking the students who are least likely to complain, and overload them with the brunt of the menial tasks they should be more responsible for. If assigned to multiple professors, they rarely communicate if at all.

review_title: DePaul does not follow ADA rules, making it very difficult to work with disabilities.
pros: Cannot think of one pro. Was very unhappy due to my issues in just getting around.
cons: DePaul does not follow the Americans with Disabilities act and does not accommodate students, faculty or staff. They pretend to use those rules, but require much more proof than is legally required. By making those requirements, disabled people give up and end up quitting.

review_title: Good place to be a student worker
pros: As a student worker you are treated very well.  They work well with your schedule.  As technical support you get a lot of the skills necessary to do this line of work elsewhere.
cons: Senior management isn't completely competent.  You're thrown into the job with little direction and little reinforcement if you get lazy.  You have to be a go-getter, like anywhere else but especially here, to excel.

review_title: Excellent environment, teaching oriented, but not much research-oriented
pros:
- It is in Chicago
- Lovely environment
- You can start teaching (as an adjunct faculty) if you are a PhD student or a successful professional
- In some departments there are real stars (e.g., a world wide known law professor, an Oscar-winner professor, ...)
- A very relaxed environment
- Course load is never a problem for a phd student
cons:
- Quite expensive if you are paying for your tuition
- NOT a research oriented department (Computer Science)
- No protection from the school against evil advisors (which is also lacking in most US schools)
- an expensive city to live in
- course prerequisites are rarely enforced, which makes course levels/speed drop to the student with least background knowledge.

review_title: Benefits can't be beat, but HR is worthless and executives can do no wrong.
pros: Fantastic benefits, work/life balance is encourage, training classes on a variety of subjects are always available for free, encourage and fund professional development, makes a very big effort to make staff/faculty feel valued which harbors a stong sense of loyalty.
cons:
HR is worthless - it took 3 months for the paperwork to go through when I was hired, and then when I got married and changed my name, I suddenly disappeared from the database and it took 2 weeks to clear up.

However, the biggest complaint (and this is huge, honestly) is that when it comes to senior staff and executives (Directors, Associate/Assistant Deans and higher) the "powers that be" protect them no matter what. I know this from colleagues who work in different offices/colleges across the university and from personal experience.  We have a senior-level staff/executive position in my department who is the absolute definition of a workplace bully, and even though this person has been reported nearly 10 times over the past 5 years, even to the Ombudsmen, there has been no disciplinary action or even any mediation to resolve the problems.  It basically feels like the University only *truly* cares about their high level staff and faculty, and everyone else can leave if they don't like it.

pros: It was a very comfortable, casual work environment. Supervisors were hands-off, which let me come up with my own tutoring style and mostly manage myself.
cons: My schedule wasn't very flexible, but it was understandable. I was working for a particular program that held office hours. I had to be there when the program took place, and I couldn't adjust my schedule for classes.

pros: None, that why turnover is so high. Horrible working environment from every angle. Paid lunch
cons: Had to work under a student who thought way too highly of themselves. Totally determental to profession of the office goals. Other staff were nice but nobody liked when you wanted your peace and quite which sucked because they were far and few in between with the high level volume. If you can try to work for any other department in the career center if u want this type of environment

pros: Working at the circulation desk is very easy.
cons: Direct supervisors are incompetent, they do not show up for their assigned tasks and several direct supervisors seem to do little work beyond moving books to and fro.  Supervisors directly ignore students, laugh at them when they make mistakes, and generally are apathetic to keeping a good workplace culture. The job itself is very easy, but is made intolerable by staff that bicker with each other more than the students do, and the student supervisors are far more caring, organized, on time, and capable than the FT supervisors.

pros: The best part about working at DePaul has been my students. Our students are diverse and many are first generation college students. Although they come differently prepared for college, they nearly all want to be transformed by their experience at DePaul and work very hard if you motivate them. There are also faculty across the University who have been working hard to fight against some of the neoliberal and racist practices of the the University. This resistance is heartening to me.
cons: Senior faculty, and white men more generally, don't do service leaving junior faculty generally and faculty of color at every level in their careers to do an excess of service. This has a serious and disparate impact on tenure and promotion and other decisions. Faculty are petty and there is so much hallway whispering. Cliques are not just about popularity but impact the distribution of department resources  and even impact votes on matters such as contract renewals and promotions. This has to stop. Finally, there has been tons of turn over in leadership during my time at DePaul--we have a new Dean, a new Provost, a new President. While this change was likely good, it seems having all the change happen at once may have led to some instability. Some faculty receive credit for doing national service while others are told that their service needs to be within the university, and this split is discretionary and seems to be discriminatory. Finally, our teaching load has remained high as research expectations have increased.

job_title: DePaul Information Services Classroom Tech in Chicago, IL
pros: Phenomenal immediate supervisors. They realize that employees are students as well, and prioritize the student over the worker part. They work with your schedule the best they can. On-the-job training people with no experience prepare for similar IT gigs.
cons: Upper management for IS tends of micromanage to a fault. Being more interested in employee behavior and rocking the boat when a single mistake is made as opposed to keeping the department from going over budget and having to cut hours as a result.

review_title: Great Place to Attend College, Worst Place to Work
pros: Education Benefits, having extra days off around Christmas when the University closes and the 403b contribution from DePaul
cons: POOR management all around, especially middle management, a budget manager with a Sociology degree who has worked there 20+ years and never took advantage of furthering her education, management just given their positions in which they didn’t work for, I reported to a micromanager for too many years and no one failed to recognize it, no mobility, no money for professional development, not enough work to do, never challenged, poor morale and an overall toxic place to work at

pros:
Great working environment, very relaxed, management are supportive, benefits are generous. Despite being a religious university, DePaul is very liberal. 

Retirement matching is generous, insurance is decent, and they have tons of other HR perks which make working for them a lot more fun and meaningful. More than a week off between Xmas and New year, and pretty good vacation structure.
cons: Salary is low, but from what I've heard, competitive in terms of higher Ed pay and compared to other schools in Chicago area.

review_title: A Great place to work as a student
pros: I worked for the School of Education and they always understood that I was a student then an employee. I always got any vacation time I needed and whenever I had an exam I was always allowed to leave a few hours early to study.
cons: Some of the management needs further training. I think working as a student should prepare you for the real world. Some of the management needs to be more realistic about the fact that they are hiring student employees and not trained professionals.

pros: Everyone is friendly and professional.  A great place to work!  Hours are flexible and you are trusted to be an independent hard worker.
cons: At times it can be difficult to know what tasks to take on but if you are a self-starter and are interested in always improving the department and students' experiences, you'll find satisfying work.

pros: Great benefits, vacation time, and colleagues. Tuition waiver = free grad school (well, almost free, - you are taxed heavily but that's on the government, not the university). I accepted the position as a way to finance grad school and don't regret it.
cons: VERY low salaries for staff, annual pay increase was laughable and below the rate of inflation. Got a small bonus my first year but that stopped. Poor morale due to job cuts. Lots of red tape trying to get anything done. Adjunct instructors overworked and underpaid.

review_title: Great job for a graduate student
pros:
-They were very flexible with my class schedule which is paramount when you are pursuing a masters degree.
-I received job training that will is relevant to my current career, but also to my aspirations for when I'm done with my masters.
-The work culture is nice.  Everybody is respectful and genuinely concerned about your well being.  By the end of my time here, my co-workers were like family.
cons:
-The pay for student workers could be higher.
-Hourly student workers received no benefits.

review_title: Top place for adjunct professors in Chicagoland University system
pros:
Good support from department.
Constant use of adjuncts provides some job stability.
Solid student body.
Fair distribution of courses.
Good location and easily accessible from El.
cons:
The lack of health benefits is difficult to accept.  
The mandated limited number of classes one can teach per year does not allow for a large salary.

pros:
-Excellent colleagues 
-motivated and intelligent graduate students
-reasonable benefit package
-good opportunities and support for community collaborations in research and teaching
cons:
-teaching load is too high
-supports negotiated in contract not consistently honored
-research productivity unreasonably high given the teaching load and service expectations
-few supports (e.g. course releases, summary salary) to support new faculty
-compensation lower than all comparable institutions in the Chicago area

pros: Laid back management, flexible hours, and very nice people. Since a lot of the employees are students themselves, there's a lot of room to work on schoolwork, move hours around, etc.
cons: Somewhat disorganized and not always comparable pay to other jobs. Most on-campus jobs are a standard $10/hour, even more specialized positions like D2L or Campus Connect C#/.NET developers.

review_title: Good place to work but there are some drawbacks
pros: Meaningful work, diverse student population, good salary, good benefits, supportive community of colleagues.
cons: The environment is not always the most professional. There is very little accountability in my division, and even if someone is grossly incompetent, there are few consequences and the person won't get fired.  Not much opportunity to move up in your career.

review_title: Great benefits but long hours and limited resources...
pros: Excellent benefits package, including full tuition waiver. State of the art campuses and facilities. Flexible work schedules and equitable performance assessment.
cons: Measurable resources devoted to recruitment, while resources are extremely lacking in the support offices dedicated to serving students once they're enrolled. Pay is not competitive, and leadership often lacks engagement.

pros: In my department, my supervisor is really nice. Compensation isn't much, but I believe they have standards for student works, and per department budget. Hours are really flexible. Workspace is okay -- I use a DePaul computer on campus and I can choose between a PC or Mac.
cons: Some of the tasks can be boring, and it takes a while to get the hang of the system. Student worker turnover is medium-high, usually someone leaves every couple of quarters, but I've been here for awhile.

job_title: Master of Fine Arts in Allison Park, PA
pros: DePaul School of Drama has an exceptional faculty, a great curriculum, and terrific 3-year plan that prepares you for real life as an artist.  Phenomenal location.
cons: Unfortunately, Chicago is expensive.  I believe the school should offer more scholarship opportunities given the talent of their alumni and the reputation those alumni garner for the University.

job_title: DePaul Information Services in Chicago, IL
pros: I worked part-time at DePaul for many years, and the whole time I worked there, I never had any issues with anyone. Sometimes, the students may be rude but the coworkers were always easy to get along & felt like a big group of friends.
cons: None that I can think of...the work can be tedious and boring slightly, but we'd have the game running while we work or take short breaks so that we don't burn out.

review_title: Over all, a pretty good job.
pros: Great people to work with, low on drama and infighting; careers in an academic environment are worthwhile. Organization seems to be forward-looking in terms of establishing its identity in an increasingly computerized world.
cons: As with all schools in the U.S., the economy and cuts in education funding make it difficult for them to hire new people.

pros: Generally laid back staff comprised of many DePaul alums. While the office culture is not particularly fun or interesting, it is not oppressive by any means.
cons: While peer experiences are generally fine, upper level management is unwilling to listen to ideas, there is high turnover in both full-time and part-time staff, and positions are underpaid against comparables.

review_title: Great benefits, but toxic environment for creativity.
pros: There are some great people who work at DePaul and the benefits  and work/life balance are outstanding. They really take care of employees. A great place to end your career.
cons: Entrenched management has created silos of workers. Environment encourages mediocrity and discourages innovation and accountability.

pros: The work environment was great, the co-workers were always very friendly, the setting wasn't terribly hierarchical and it made it easy to talk to be an active participant in the center, even as a student.
cons: They offered lots of time for reflecting on the work (definitely an important thing to do), but it wasn't always very organized.

pros: It's very comfortable to work here, my workmates are very nice! We have enough vocation every year.
cons: Actually, I didn't find any downside of my job so far. If I have to say something, the job maybe is not very challenging.

review_title: Student focused and supportive of staff development
pros: DePaul has a long history of committment to student development and education.  From academic affairs to student affairs, students are encouraged to effectively engage in their communities and think critically about their roles within.  DePaul also supports the passions and professional goals of staff and faculty.
cons: As a medium to large-sized instituation, there can sometimes be systems or policies that don't always account for the many diverse needs of students, staff, and faculty.

pros: There are lots of Pros for the DePaul Career Center. Well funded area of the University so it is expanding in roles. It has a very friendly environment and company culture as well.
cons: There isn't much to say. A lot of people are very stuck in their ways and planning can be a bit organized. Overall, it's a great opportunity.

pros: Very lack-back environment. Candy provided. Not much thing to do so you can focus on your own assignment s.
cons: Your supervisor basically never show up. So don't expected someone will taking care of you. Students sometimes not very care about their works.

review_title: Continual Chaotic management and turbulence in leadership
pros: Great location, excellent classrooms, great technology and physical grounds.  Excellent shops and clean surroundings.  Personable students and faculty.  Beautiful campus.
cons: Salaries frozen for 3 years for faculty and may continue due to sagging enrollments and a new stadium.  Racial tension with protests.  Department  heads are pawns of deans.  New president next year, new provost last year, new dean this year.  Changing standards on evaluations and promotion.  Beware!  Part time faculty were starting to unionize.

job_title: DePaul Athletics Marketing Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: DePaul athletics also introduces you yo the ins and outs of working in college sports. It was truly a great hub  for refining your business skills
cons: DePaul athletics also introduces you yo the ins and outs of working in college sports, & learning how to market to the public. But it would be great if they could allow students be more hands on with learning & dealing with finances as well, to provide the full experience

pros: Provided outlet for me to give back to profession and train future work candidates.  Ample autonomy in creating course curriculum and teaching course
cons: Not many avenues open to recruit students for your classes if they are not on core curriculum

pros: Good benefits, friendly people, value and mission oriented.  I really enjoy working here.  A lot of the employees have been here for 10 years or more.
cons: Very student oriented so sometimes staff feel forgotten about. It would be nice if the pay were higher but it's a school so you know what you're getting into.

review_title: DePaul Feels Like Home to Employees
pros: Flexible work environment, university setting is vibrant with plenty of resources and opportunities for students and staff, people who work at DePaul end up staying for many years as they really enjoy it and find a home here.
cons: The campus is split between Loop and Lincoln Park locations which is a bit tricky for scheduling meetings and events, but the L works well and students/staff/faculty are used to making the 15ish minute trek.

review_title: Great if you have no motivation!
pros: Extreme comfort, low stress, nobody cares, deadlines mean nothing, absolutely zero accountability for being bad at your job. You don't even have to show up! If you have friends or family that already work here, you'll get a job no problem!
cons: Nobody cares, deadlines mean nothing,absolutely zero accountability. You lose absolutely all of your motivation for what you thought may be a career.

pros: Because the faculty of DePaul University are not just professors, the opportunity to network and to be a part of a group of people that excels is amazing!
cons: Unless you have many years of experience in your field, they will not even give you a look.

pros: While each division varies, I found DePaul to be very supportive of family obligations and very amenable to working things out so that the work gets done and any family emergencies can be addressed.  DePaul also strives to keep compensation market based.
cons: The student population is shrinking, so DePaul has had staff cutbacks in some areas.

review_title: Good place to work while earning a degree
pros: Great environment for good will, many opportunities for helping the under privileged.  Jobs at DePaul mean something to each and every student.  Faculty and Staff governance helps bring issues to Senior management.  Free tuition for employees and their immediate families.
cons: Poor Senior Management decision transparency, people in management roles with no training in management.  Little chance for promotion.  Low pay.

pros: The people are very friendly, and the management is very flexible. The hours are good, and the pay is very competitive.
cons: The opportunity for advancement is very limited almost by definition as a student employee. Also sometimes Payroll at DePaul doesn't work very well.

job_title: Software Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Everyone in my department was friendly. Good flexibility in choosing hours to work around class schedule. Worked on interesting projects to gain experience. Supervisor was friendly and easy to get along with.
cons: Some projects weren't as exciting as others. Some days I didn't have all that much work to do. Communication between managers and other co-workers could have been better.

review_title: Excellent for the right type of person.
pros: Excellent if you're looking to move onto grad school as it provides publication opportunities and insight into academia you may not have had before, as well as a large amount of resources and information to assist if graduate school is your goal.
cons: Pay can be quite low, especially when attempting to pay student debt and maintain somewhat of a social life in an expensive city.

review_title: I had learned from people that went to top tier schools in classes that were very small.
pros: The faculty was quite good while I was there.  There was ample opportunity to do undergraduate research.
cons: The Chemistry department has gone down hill since I was there from what I have heard.  There seem to have been quite a few missteps in the vetting process for new hire of tenure tracked professors.

pros: Loved working at DePaul. The students were awesome and actual learning experience was probably the best out of all the places I've taught.
cons: Parking downtown was not optimal and got expensive. Elevators take quite a while to come and caused me to be late some time.

pros: Easy work in the computer labs watching over students doing their homework. Would recommend trying to work at DePaul while studying there
cons: Some Management not too good. They get hired from the student population as well and they don't always know that much about actual management.

job_title: Classroom Technology Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: It is great to have your schedule based around your classes. Also, commuting is not a problem since the job is on campus.
cons: Mininum wage job and there is a limit of 25 hours per week. Also, the university does not offer any raises based on performance or years of experience.

job_title: Information Services Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Learning experience working with many departments outside of Information Technology. Very flexible hours and scheduling opportunities for student employees.
cons: Limited hourly pay and excessive bureaucracy. As a student employee pay raises were rare and had a hard upward limit.

review_title: Great culture & benefits, but heavily siloed.
pros: Incredible benefits and work-life balance, friendly and supportive culture, brilliant colleagues, and lots of networking opportunities.
cons: Everything is heavily siloed. Processes can easily get backed up and disrupted. It can be hard to get in touch with the right person, but once you do they are eager to help. The tech involved can be pretty boring depending on what kind of work you're doing.

review_title: Good Experience Overall for a Solid Resume Builder
pros: It is a tight knit family of professionals.  Everyone is open to help each other out when possible and everyone is very professional.  It's an inviting place to work.
cons: Tasks could be monotonous at times.  Sometimes defined projects were unorganized and unclear.  Seemed a little "political" where advancement wasn't based on performance, but more so on personal opinions.

pros:
Good benefits package
Most colleagues are pleasant to work with
cons:
Tenure rewarded before talent
No upward mobility
Minimal communication between departments
Management is determined by who is next in line
Donors and students receive exponentially more care and consideration than employees

review_title: Decent for student employment, but staff professionals are burned out
pros: Great colleagues, everyone wants to better the lives of the students. Safe environment.
cons: poor management and leadership skills. This extends to top VPs and provost. They are not listening to the people on the ground, the field, what is needed to support the students

pros:
The position allows you to taking your own initiatives as well as having an say in decisions.
The work environment is very relaxed. I have worked in different department and some departments are better than others.
cons: Do not pay a lot for the student worker job. The jobs are time were not challenging at all.

pros: Everything is great.  The leadership team is great.  The benefits are awesome and the students are great.  I wouldn't leave for anything.
cons: not enough money.  I can go on and on, but that wouldn't change anything.  Great place to work however.

pros: Professors work with you to help craft jobs that allow you to apply skills that you are still working on. You can work within or outside of your academic department.
cons: There is  a lot of competition for the top jobs, and there may not be many hours available.

pros: Coworkers feel like family. Everyone in my department is clearly in love with the subject we teach, and that is a very welcoming and infectious environment.
cons: The administration caters too much to a vocal minority of students. More trust needs to be put in the faculty, specifically tenured/tenure track faculty.

pros: As a student worker, DePaul understands the importance of general career training, mentoring and constructive advice. My manager is a fantastic person and the institution is dedicated to a great cause.
cons: Due to the nature of the position, there is not much opportunity for advancement, unless you excel at what you do and they offer a full time position upon graduation.

pros: Open minded administration and the students are/were top notch.
cons: Too much centralized power with certain rigidid, narrowminded Associate Deans. Too few as well. Not enough staff. Too many adjuncts. Part-time to full-time faculty ratio is horrible.

pros: Avg. $9 an hour pay, better than minimum wage. Positive environment, flexible scheduling. The university wants you to succeed, so they understand if you have to make school a priority over student work.
cons: At least where I was working, the number of hours per week was capped. The idea was to keep the student from falling behind on study.

pros: The people I work with are great and very understanding of my school schedule.  Made a lot of great friends here too.
cons: There are not really any cons to working here.  They really work with you to help make it a great time.

pros: super fun atmosphere. you will work with great people!
cons: The field just switched management and things are becoming more and more strict. You can no longer be seen with your phone or reading, while waiting for someone to pick up. you must sit and stare at a screen your entire shift and listen to ringing

review_title: A truly mission-driven institution that treats its employees like family. A joy to work there.
pros: Great benefits and quality of life; positive social impact in Chicago and beyond; opportunities to move around the university once employed.
cons: Salaries cannot compete with industry/corporate; some offices are very flat--no opportunities for advancement--so after a few years you need to move on.

pros:
- Great team
- People gave me room to be creative 
- Get paid well 
- higher education 
- I got peer network and experience
cons:
- nothing much
- slow paced 
I think that's what higher education work environment looks like

pros: Great coworker; very nice work atmosphere if you can ignore the politics - which by no means bad - just regular. Learning opportunities; 35-hrs. works week and good vacation time. Technologically cutting-edge in higher education
cons: Politics only if you get into it. Upward mobility is somewhat limited due to favoritism.

pros:
Work freedom
Pay is among the highest for like universities
benefits are comprehensive
schedule has lots of vacation and down time
cons:
Committees postpone decisions rather than making them
Administrative overhead, Way to many administrators
Rather orthodox liberal PC culture

pros: Great work life balance, good training and development opportunities, opportunity for advancement, discounted tuition, a lot of passionate people who really care about their jobs and the students.
cons: Because it is a university and they can be lenient, there are definitely people who don't do a lot of work, spend all day online, and still have a job.

pros: Get to know professors. Free tuition + stipend. Professors are accommodating of class schedules. You are not assigned work during finals week. Most professors are good about sticking to guidelines about workload.
cons: Variation in tasks/workload between professors/departments. The tasks could be more challenging.

pros: Extremely diverse, learn a lot about the academia lifestyle
cons: Like all places, communication sometimes slips through the cracks and it pays the price.

pros: Its great to work at DePaul as a student employee. There are great opportunities and also flexibility. Managers often allow students to get flexible hours of work based on their class load. This is how things were when I was a student 4-5 years ago.
cons: Pay can be OK, but it depends on the position and department.

job_title: Office of Advancement Employee in Chicago, IL
pros:
-Great benefits
-Great people
-Great Management
-Fun and professional environment
-Welcoming community
-Great room for advancement
-great feeling of helping others
cons:
-Repetitious work
-Some days are extremely busy and some days are extremely slow
- Not too much wrong with this position

pros: A majority of the people I've encountered and worked with are very kind, intelligent, and professional. They are very accommodating and emphasize a work/life/school balance. The work is what you make it. If you choose to, you can take on additional projects and learn more than your position originally entailed. Overall would recommend.
cons: Pay is low for student employees

review_title: Great job to have while being a student!
job_title: Student Lab Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: I enjoyed being a Lab Assistant and everything that I learned from the people I met. The University was very understanding and accommodating to my student schedule. It was a great experience working within the University I attended.
cons: Other than normal job challenges, there are not any cons I have to list.

review_title: Great University, but political and in debt
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: DePaul is a very good university and cares deeply about its students. Great faculty development and some research funding opportunities.
cons: Deeply in debt and hiring mostly Visiting faculty, and not many TT. Tenure is increasingly difficult to get, and tends to be highly politicized.

pros: The office culture is great. The staff and supervisors are friendly and helpful. Won't tolerate tardiness or tedious behavior on the job, which is good
cons: Nothing bad to say about my work experience at this university because my coworkers and supervisors were friendly and great staff to work with

pros:
Great benefits 
Great learning opportunities 
Nice people
cons:
Unfair advancement practices 
Poor salaries 
Rules do not apply equally throughout all depts

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Faculty and students are all very welcoming. Coming from an outside institution I didn't know what to expect. I couldn't have been more impressed by the quality and character of all my co-workers here at DePaul.
cons: Some weeks get busy with grading towards the end of the quarter, but that is the nature of the job!

review_title: I enjoyed working here. Truly a fulfilling experience!
job_title: Information Services Employee in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Loved the culture
- Very laid back
- Everyone is kind and supportive
- As long as you get your work done, no one really cares if you're listening to music and walking around.
cons: None - This school is based on Venetian faith, but I'm glad it's not a religious work environment.

pros: The travel time was not far, the hourly pay was above the minimum wage, and there are tons of stores and restaurants nearby.
cons: There did not appear to be much room to advance professional and there was no full time available in the department where I worked for almost 4 years.

review_title: Good benefits and a good mission, but very bureaucratic.
pros: Great benefits, including tuition waiver for you and your family. Relatively laid back, although perhaps not as flexible as it could be.
cons: Very bureaucratic environment. Very political. Par for the course for a University though. It's a tough time for this field as well.

pros: Great benefits. Hard to beat.
cons: Extremely underpaid. Bureaucratic and weighed down by internal politics. Staff under-appreciated and undervalued. 2% raises every year, on a good year.

pros: good resesarch staff , extensive experience of facutly . futuristic research challenges being tackled. Friendly faculty , open for suggestions.
cons:
More funding towards research would be great. 
Not great stipends for doctoral candidates, is kind of discouraging

job_title: Director of Development in Chicago, IL
pros: Work-Life balance is fair for staff who have families  and colleagues are talented and welcoming. A good place to learn.
cons: Gabriel Esteban has a very different style than his predecessors.  Alumni and staff are unhappy and very concerned about the future. Salary is not competitive compared to other universities.

pros: Friendly staff, flexible hours and great way to practice people skills in an IT environment
cons: Politics (chain of who was supposed to do what), behind in the IT department in regards to accessibility and software services,

pros: The University has great benefits and really supports staff with health incentive programs and health workshops. It's a happy place to work.
cons: Not every department has a great atmosphere. And, like most universities, there are people in positions of power who have been there a long time and are incompetent. Nowhere is perfect.

pros: good place to work at. communicating through different offices is friendly and easy. Hours seem to be pretty flexible. benefits package. interesting lunch sessions that you can sit on. 2 week december break
cons: things can get very unorganized within your office. communication between each there, but more on a personal level.

review_title: Admin/clerical staff = empty nester / put my kids through college
pros: Tuition benefits for dependents are ok.
cons: Middle-management heavy organization with management unwilling to delegate and performing responsibilities that are typically handled by admin/clerical staff. Disjointed silo-style operations. Very limited professional development opportunities for clerical/admin staff. "Old boys network" style relationships. Admin staff salaries do not match market.

review_title: Great place for development for undergrad students

- Great coworkers, everyone very friendly 
- Supervisors and more wanted us to succeed, provided support and opportunities

- Lots of good experience
cons: - Occasionally lots of downtime, good if you have some school work or studying to do but the days can get very long sometimes

review_title: Depaul university controllers office - financial accounting intern
job_title: Financial Accounting Intern in Chicago, IL

cons: Very hard to get a full time offer and your stuck with doing the same stuff day in and day out

review_title: Great place for a student job.
pros: A part time job here is often quite easy, and leaves lots of time for doing homework or studying. Training is quick, and it does pay more than minimum wage. Supervisors are very understanding about your schedule as a student.
cons: Not often relevant experience. Mind numbingly dull.

review_title: Intellectual work environment with the possibility to work with  professors and fellow students.
pros: Intellectual learning environment. Some work allows for access to classes. Student pay isn't great but the benefits of classes and the overall access to a university learning environment are worth it.
cons: Not all departments would be great to work in.

pros: Collegial, diverse, challenging and so much to learn. Employers encourages growth.  Easy to become part of work culture because folks are welcoming.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Chicago, IL
pros: If you like working at a slow-paced environment then DePaul is for you. I also love all the employee benefits and free events you can go to!

review_title: DePaul Athletics Marketing and Licensing Intern
job_title: DePaul Athletics Marketing Assistant in Chicago, IL

cons: The pay was not that great most interns made only about $9-10 per hour. Sometimes the work can be frustrating or even boring.

job_title: Marketing and Communications Coordinator in Chicago, IL

cons: Low salary for my particular role, not much room for moving up, upper management have no clue.

pros: Quarter system results in decent pay compared to other schools
cons: Have benefits but do not pay enough for adjuncts to use them. Full timers display distinct caste approach. Money should be better.

pros: If you're lucky you can meet some real great people depending on the department you work for. Most people are hard workers and truly care about what they do but those kind of people do not exist in upper management positions.

pros:
-Forward-thinking leadership
-Values employees as a resource

-Mission and service-oriented
-Diverse student population and employees

pros: The location is central and the benefits are good.

review_title: It was an experience that promoted growth and helped me to over challenges.
job_title: Service Learning Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Diversity, team  building, personal growth and development, culture, life skills, time management,
cons: The only problem is there were short hours.

review_title: Great experience with the university's internal budgeting department

cons: nothing that i can think of

pros: Flexible, you can do the work at any place. And the working hours is totally up to you.

pros: Great location. Smart people. Lab has multiple ways for founding.Pressure is at acceptable level and some of the professors are really nice

pros: Wonderful co-workers and interesting work, part-time benefits aren't great but they have them and are easy to access.

review_title: This is a nice and welcoming community.

review_title: "Here We Do" Caring and Entrepreneurial Urban Academic Environment

cons: Need to do more training and development leading to  promotion from within.

pros: Depends on the department, but the working environment is great. Strong culture and values. Very nice colleagues, managers are supportive and collaborative. Good benefits including tuition waiver, unlimited sick, and generous vacation time off. Nice 403b matching as well.

pros: This was the best working environment and team I've ever had. I worked there almost 7 years on and off and only regret I couldn't build my career there permanently.

review_title: It is great I really enjoy it.

review_title: Great place to work at especially as an undergrad
pros: Flexible scheduling, good pay, free housing and meal plan
cons: pay isn't as high as it should be but you get free housing so i can not complain

pros: My department chair is very supportive and gives me wide latitude to shape my courses. My experience with DePaul students has also been positive; they are generally engaged and hard-working.

review_title: Okay place to work as a student

pros: Decent pay. Excellent students. Inclusion in meetings makes one feel he/she is part of the team.

review_title: Relaxed, paced environment. Not great for non-academic career.

pros: Great culture, Amazing school in the heart of the second city. The school is equipped with all the resources needed. I worked with top researchers in Technology, Science and Business. It was fun and I loved this job,

review_title: Pretty fun depending on the team.
